texts.shortText: Previously included along with what is now known as the Pacific humpback dolphin as a single species, Sousa chinensis, but the two regional forms shown to be separate species in a 2014 study.

Robust dolphin with a stocky body that tends to be flattened towards the tail. Has a longish, narrow beak and white-tipped jaw. Dorsal fin small and hooked and set onto a large, broad, distinctive fleshy hump, after which the species is named. There are 33–38 stout teeth in each upper jaw and 30–37 in each lower jaw.

Upper body plain brownish-grey, with a paler belly. Often bear prominent scars on flanks, suggestive of predation attempts by large sharks.

Can also be recognised in the field by its steeply-arching surfacing behaviour.
Length of males up to 2.8 m and mass 150–200 kg. Females considerably smaller, not exceeding 2.5 m.

Global: Widely distributed across the Indian Ocean from South Africa up the east coast of Africa and the Middle East to India. Replaced in China and the western Pacific by the closely related S. chinensis and in Australia by S. sahulensis.

Local/Regional: From False Bay eastwards into Mozambique. Not on west coast.

Usually found in shallow waters close to the coast, rarely in water deeper than 15 m, but can occur several km offshore if water is shallow. Uncommon and usually found in small groups averaging about 12 individuals. Non-migratory and have a characteristic motion when surfacing, showing the beak and head first, then arching the back and diving to show the flukes as they submerge.

Often show scars inflicted by sharks suggesting that shark predation is a significant cause of mortality. Also particularly vulnerable to human induced disturbances including coastal pollution, habitat alteration, capture in shark nets, vessel strikes, noise etc. Calves tend to exhibit high rates of morality and tissues of stranded specimens often show high levels of chemical pollution. The South African population is estimated at only about 500 individuals, so the species is of conservation concern.

Feeds on a wide variety of fish, cephalopods and crustaceans. May work as a group to herd fish and have been observed driving shoals of fish onto exposed sandbanks and then deliberately beaching themselves to capture the exposed fish.

Females reach sexual maturity at an age of about 9–10 years and males at only 12–14 years. Gestation period is 10–12 and births take place mostly in summer. Calves are nursed for up to 24 month and may remain with the mother for at least 3–4 years. This results in an unusually long calving interval of about 5 years. Calves are born at a length of about 100 cm.
Unlikely to be confused with other local species due the diagnostic hump around the dorsal fin.
